user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of setup_epoll_fd:
```c
static int
setup_epoll_fd (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon)
{
  int fd;

#ifndef HAVE_MESSAGES
  (void) daemon; /* Mute compiler warning. */
#endif /* ! HAVE_MESSAGES */

#ifdef USE_EPOLL_CREATE1
  fd = epoll_create1 (EPOLL_CLOEXEC);
#else  /* ! USE_EPOLL_CREATE1 */
  fd = epoll_create (MAX_EVENTS);
#endif /* ! USE_EPOLL_CREATE1 */
  if (MHD_INVALID_SOCKET == fd)
  {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    MHD_DLOG (daemon,
              _ ("Call to epoll_create1 failed: %s\n"),
              MHD_socket_last_strerr_ ());
#endif
    return MHD_INVALID_SOCKET;
  }
#if ! defined(USE_EPOLL_CREATE1)
  if (! MHD_socket_noninheritable_ (fd))
  {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    MHD_DLOG (daemon,
              _ ("Failed to set noninheritable mode on epoll FD.\n"));
#endif
  }
#endif /* ! USE_EPOLL_CREATE1 */
  return fd;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function setup_epoll_fd:
#define HAVE_MESSAGES 1
...
#define USE_EPOLL_CREATE1 1
...
#define MAX_EVENTS 128
...
#define MHD_INVALID_SOCKET (-1)
...
void
MHD_DLOG (const struct MHD_Daemon *daemon,
          const char *format,
          ...)
{
  va_list va;

  if (0 == (daemon->options & MHD_USE_ERROR_LOG))
    return;
  va_start (va, format);
  daemon->custom_error_log (daemon->custom_error_log_cls,
                            format,
                            va);
  va_end (va);
}
...
#define _(String) (String)
...
#define MHD_socket_last_strerr_ MHD_socket_strerr_(MHD_socket_get_error_())
...
int
MHD_socket_noninheritable_ (MHD_socket sock)
{
#if defined(MHD_POSIX_SOCKETS)
  int flags;

  flags = fcntl (sock,
                 F_GETFD);
  if (-1 == flags)
    return 0;

  if ( ((flags | FD_CLOEXEC) != flags) &&
       (0 != fcntl (sock,
                    F_SETFD,
                    flags | FD_CLOEXEC)) )
    return 0;
#elif defined(MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS)
  if (! SetHandleInformation ((HANDLE) sock,
                              HANDLE_FLAG_INHERIT,
                              0))
    return 0;
#endif /* MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS */
  return ! 0;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
#else  /* ! USE_EPOLL_CREATE1 */
  fd = epoll_create (MAX_EVENTS);
#endif /* ! USE_EPOLL_CREATE1 */
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The #else branch (fd = epoll_create(MAX_EVENTS);) is excluded by the preprocessor because USE_EPOLL_CREATE1 is defined as 1 in the provided configuration. That code is not part of the compiled translation unit, so there is no runtime-unreachable statement inside the built project. Therefore Rule 2.1 is not violated in this configuration. (If a different build configuration undefines USE_EPOLL_CREATE1, the other branch would be compiled instead; either way there is no unreachable code within a single compiled build.)
